huntBios.GENERAL_INFORMATION: This hunt unit is located in low elevation desert.  Much of the unit has been heavily impacted by oil and gas development so there are a lot of roads in the unit where pronghorn can be seen from.
huntBios.SAFETY_CONS: Cellular phone coverage is good on this hunt unit.  A "Spot Tracker" type of satellite messaging device for safety can be used if you decide to camp in an area without cell phone service and do not wish to drive to reach service.  Make sure someone knows where you plan to camp and when you will return.
huntBios.WEATHER_CONS: The weather on this hunt unit can vary dramatically between the hunting seasons.  Be prepared for rain, lightning, wind and heat.  It is quite common on clear mornings for clouds to build through the morning and have thunderstorms in the afternoon.  Be very cautious of lightning while hunting on high ridges or exposed slopes.
huntBios.MANAGEMENT_OBJ: 97.4~1200~475~~~2.0–3.0~4.3~~~~~~For more detailed information on population and objective data please see the Big Game Annual Report Page.
huntBios.BIOLOGIST_NOTES:
Pronghorn rut:
The pronghorn rut usually starts the end of September so it does not really affect the hunt.

Scouting Tips:
Pronghorn are fairly habitual and can be found in the same general area from late summer through the hunt. Pronghorn are best scouted from a distance using a spotting scope or binoculars so they don’t leave the area. They are most active in the morning and evening when the temperatures are cooler. This area has been heavily impacted by energy development. There are a lot of roads from the energy development so hunters should have no problem finding pronghorn.

Behavior:
Like other wildlife, they are most active in the early mornings and evenings, but they can be up and moving any time of the day. Most of the time they are in desert scrub/sagebrush flat areas. If the weather is extremely hot, they will often seek shade during the middle part of the day. Pronghorn are herd animals. You will often see groups of does and fawns with only a few bucks mixed in during the fall. During the rut, bucks will separate from other males to find does to mate with. The rest of the year, the bucks are usually with other pronghorn.

Buck vs Doe:
Hunters can tell bucks from does by several characteristics. Bucks will have larger horns and a black cheek patch.

Where to find pronghorn:
90% of the pronghorn are found on public lands in desert scrub and sagebrush flat areas. They typically stay out of heavily treed and cliffy areas. Pronghorn are found near water sources. Pronghorn are not typically found on Diamond Mountain.

Recommended areas in the Bonanza/Diamond Mtn:
Good areas to hunt include Deadman Bench, Coyote Basin, Glen Bench, and Snake John. Diamond Mountain subunit is not recommended due to either no or very few pronghorn.

huntMaster.NOTES:
Baiting big game for the purposes of hunting is now illegal in Utah.
Click here for more information.

The use of all trail cameras (including both non-handheld transmitting and non-transmitting devices) in the harvest or to aid in the harvest of big game is prohibited between July 31 and Dec. 31. Click here for more information.
huntMaster.HARVEST_REPORTING: REQUIRED: click here or call 1-800-221-0659 to report your harvest. You must report your harvest, even if you did not take an animal, within 30 days of the season end date that is printed on your permit; failure to do so may result in you not being able to apply for big game species in subsequent years. Submitting teeth or other biological samples from your animal, or having your animal checked by a DWR representative or CWMU operator does NOT fulfill your mandatory harvest reporting requirement.

huntBoundaryInfos.CAMPGRND_INFO:
All campgrounds on this unit are managed by the US Forest Service and BLM. Camping outside of official campgrounds is also permitted on most of the public lands. Please direct all questions regarding campground availability and other camping questions to the US Forest Service. Maps and camping regulations are available on their websites.
Ashley National Forest: http://www.fs.usda.gov/main/ashley/home
huntBoundaryInfos.SUGGESTED_MAPS: USGS 1:100,000 Vernal and Dutch John topo maps
huntBoundaryInfos.ATV_VEH_ACCESS:
Most roads and ATV trails on this unit are managed by the BLM and are covered on their Travel Management Plan. Please direct all questions regarding which roads and trails ATVs can be operated on to the BLM.
BLM: http://www.blm.gov/ut/st/en/fo/vernal.html

Most areas are closed to off road vehicle use except on designated routes.
huntBoundaryInfos.PRIV_TRIBE_LAND_ISSUES: The boundary of this hunt unit includes some Tribal Trust Lands and does have private land included.  Hunters should receive written permission from private landowners prior to the start of the hunts if they wish to hunt private property.  Hunting Tribal lands is not permitted.
huntBoundaryInfos.BOUNDARY_DESCRIPTION: Daggett and Uintah counties—Boundary begins at the Green River and the Utah-Colorado state line near Browns Park; west along this river to Gorge Creek; south along Gorge Creek to the USFS/private land boundary at the head of Davenport Draw; south along the USFS/private land boundary on the west side of Davenport Draw to the BLM boundary; south along the BLM boundary approximately one-third of a mile to the rim of Diamond Mountain; south and easterly along this rim until the rim intersects the Diamond Mountain road (Jones Hole Road); southwest along this road to the Brush Creek road; south along this road to the Island Park-Rainbow Park road; east along this road to the Dinosaur National Monument boundary; west and south on this boundary to the Green River; southwest along the Green River to the White River; east along this river to the Utah-Colorado state line; north on this state line to the Green River near Browns Park. EXCLUDING ALL NATIVE AMERICAN TRUST LAND WITHIN THIS BOUNDARY.  EXCLUDES DINOSAUR NATIONAL MONUMENT.  USGS 1:100,000 Maps: Dutch John, Vernal. Boundary questions? Call the Vernal office, 435-781-9453.
